titleproper.value: Guide to the Abraham Levine Papers <num>TAM.693</num>

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

abstract.value:
The Abraham Levine Papers (dated
        1938-1948) consist of correspondence and drafts related to Abraham Levine's political
        activities. Levine was a rank-and-file member of Trotskyist movement, and his papers provide
        a window into the ways in which everyday members of the movement interpreted current affairs
        in the 1940s. His papers include correspondence with fellow members of the Trotskyist
        movement, and several drafts of essays reflecting on current events, international politics,
        and American trade and commerce from a leftist perspective.

extent.value: in 1 manuscript box and 1 half manuscript box

physloc.Text:
Materials are stored offsite and advance
        notice is required for use. Please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu at least two business
        days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

p.value:
Identification of item, date; Abraham Levine Papers; TAM 693; box number; folder number;
        Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University

Donated by Ellen Bitkower in 2017. The accession number associated with this gift is
        2017.030.

Abraham Levine was a rank-and-file member of Trotskyist movement. Although Levine did not
        hold a leadership position in any political organization, he was an active member in New
        York City area Trotskyist groups including the Communist Workers' Group.

The Abraham Levine Papers (dated 1938-1948) consist of correspondence and drafts related to
        Abraham Levine's political activities. Levine was a rank-and-file member of Trotskyist
        movement, and his papers provide a window into the ways in which everyday members of the
        movement interpreted current affairs in the 1940s. His papers include correspondence with
        fellow members of the Trotskyist movement, and several drafts of essays reflecting on
        current events, international politics, and American trade and commerce from a leftist
        perspective.

This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the
        order in which they were received from the donor.
